title: How to address formally two persons in an email - Quora

response.answer_text: Prior to the midpoint of the last century, the formal way to address two individuals was (male): Messrs or (female) Madams. For example, “Dear Messers Smith and Brown”. It was a bit more complicated when some recipients were male and others female. With two recipients, you would simply write “Dear Miss Smith and Mr. Brown”. (Prior to Gloria Steinem in the late 1960s, a woman was always Mrs. Or Miss. Later, the salutation changed to “Ms”). If a man was under 18 and unmarried, his title was Master. Just as C-3PO says “Yes, Master Luke”. But, I doubt that this would be advised in any modern manual of style or etiquette today. It's just too arcane. I suspect that others answering this question will disagree with my position. But, I feel that in most any scenario, today—even formal or when addressing a superior—it is safe to address multiple individuals by their first names in writing. Yes! I am even suggesting that upon returning from a job interview, it is not inappropriate to write a letter that begins “Dear Dave and Susan” — at least not if you established a bit of rapport, and exchanged a few smiles during your brief time together. There are definitely a few exceptions: In the case of royalty or recipients with a political / judicial title, anyone who has been knighted, and high Church officials. These are very special cases. It should be noted that the United States never grants honorary titles, but we still show judges, senators and members of congress similar titular respect. Incidentally, we do not do this for the president. It is “Mr. Obama” or “Mr. President. it is always wrong to address him as President Obama. This is a long-standing convention which highlights the fact that the United States is a democracy, and rejects nobility in its own government. Let’s look at the exceptions. These are the cases for which I would still use a formal title… In the case of a bishop or The Pope, you would use the deferential phrases: Your Grace, Eminence or Holiness — addressing each individual separately, even if you are not a member of their faith. With a King, Queen or Prince, you would refer to them as your Royal Highness; and with a military commander (while you serve in any military capacity), you would address them by their rank. There may be a few other cases, but with lesser nobility (dukes and duchesses) or lesser politicians (ambassador, assemblyman, council members, etc), you should feel perfectly comfortable using a first name in any multi-recipient communication—even if you are not generally on a first-name basis with each individual.

In a formal letter, if you know their names, you address them with “Dear Mr. White and Mr. Black”; “Dear Ms. Green and Ms. Gold”; “Dear Ms. Smith and Mr. Jones”; or if they’re married, “Dear Mr. and Mrs. Williams.” If you don’t know their names, but you know one is male and one female, “Dear Sir and Madam.” If you don’t know their names but both are male, I’d suggest “Gentlemen.” If you don’t know their names but both are female, I’d suggest “Ladies:” (although traditionally it was “Mesdames:”). I believe you’d want the same greetings in a “formal” e-mail as in a letter. Footnotes: (1) Fifty years ago, if there were several addressees and you didn’t know any names, the letter had to begin simply “Gentlemen:” Please note, not “Dear Gentlemen,” just “Gentlemen:” Now, we begin with “Ladies and Gentlemen:” (again, not “Dear Ladies and Gentlemen”). (2) Sadly, there are ill-informed people who are wrongheaded enough to object to “Madam” or “Ladies” for women as somehow sexist and insulting and object to “Gentlemen” for men as, I don’t know, elitist or otherwise politically incorrect. Unwilling to use words like “Madam,” “Ladies” or “Gentlemen,” they put forward all sorts of awful-sounding workarounds. My advice is that the traditional words showing respect should still be acceptable among enlightened, well-mannered people. Hillary Rodham Clinton as Secretary of State was “Madam Secretary,” and why not?
